The world of La Gias, situated inside our Earth. For millennia, the Holy Kingdom of Langran ruled over the lands of La Gias with its long, proud history and an unprecedented level of technology. However, the days of the kingdom are numbered. Seers and scholars predict that the mighty state will fall in the next 10 years, thus bringing forth the destruction of their world. In an effort to stave off such a terrible prediction, Langran produces powerful machines, called the Masou Kishin, powered by pilot's sheer willpower, called "prāna". The majority of the people of Langran however, do not possess enough willpower to control these giant mechanical beings. In their last ditch effort, the kingdom summons a few people from the Surface (Earth). Among them is Masaki Andō, a man that will rise to the challenge of putting an end to an almost invincible evil.

Masou Kishin The Lord of Elemental is the first Super Robot Wars/Taisen game that does not feature any licensed franchises; instead, it tells the story of the original characters that were previously introduced in SRW 2, 3, EX and 4. Like its contemporaries, it is a turn-based tactical RPG game. The player goes through a comprehensive campaign, battling against enemies and leveling up their units. After battles, players can upgrade their units' stats. Alongside the battles, players experience the story through the eyes of the main protagonist and make important choices that can have an impact on how the story plays out.

While the core gameplay remains relatively the same as that of the previous classic Super Robot Wars/Taisen titles, Masou Kishin introduced a number of features that would be implemented in later games of the franchise. For one, the graphics are vastly enhanced: robots are represented in actual proportions during battle, instead of the "super-deformed" look of the previous titles. The battlefield is now in isometric position, compared to the top-down view of the previous titles. The isometric view also allows for more tactical depth: units attacking from behind deal greater damage than attacking from the front. Terrain also affects unit stats that can give a notable advantage over the enemy.
title: Super Robot Taisen Gaiden: Masou Kishin - The Lord of Elemental

description:
Fork Parker's Crunch Out is a homebrew game starring Fork Parker, the fictional CFO of Devolver Digital. It was created to raise awareness about "crunch time" in game development, a practice in some companies when employees are expected to put in a large amount of (unpaid) overtime hours to get the game done in a proposed time. Devolver Digital donated 100% of their profits from sales to Take This, an organization that raises awareness and aims to combat mental health issues.

At the start of the game Fork Parker feels threatened by the rise of a new publisher, Cash Cow Games. They released Loot Box: The Game where only one in twenty downloads contains the actual game and they bought their own e-sports team. Parker decides it is time to catch up with them through crunch time. The player controls Parker in the office with mechanics typical of time management titles. He needs to bring employees caffeine to keep them awake, serve hamburgers at their desks, whip them into working, literally, using a bat, or resuscitate them using a dose of electricity when they pass out. The game takes place on a single, fixed screen and most actions are tied to moving to one of the four stations near the top of the screen, for instance to get coffee. An icon of an employee's head shows the current mood / status and Parker needs to move quickly to the correct station to remedy it. There is also a pink pet pig Pork running around and it needs to be avoided. When Parker comes in contact with it, he shakes it for a long time and B needs to be tapped repeatedly to make him let go.

Levels last only five minutes and then the developers' game needs to be done, with progress shown through a bar near the top of the screen. The first level starts with four developers, but the number of people increases with every new stage. Between levels, upgrades can be bought using money. Upgrades affect the stations, but also Parker himself. For instance increasing his movement speed, reducing the time he pets Pork, healing all negative status effects or earning 30 seconds of unpaid overtime. The latter are either single-use items or only last a single day, while the station upgrades are permanent.

Coins constantly appear between the desks and Parker needs to collect these to purchase the upgrades. There are also a large number of additional mini-games to play. These are tied to the development, such as completing a mini-game to fix the internet that has gone out so all development is halted. In another mini-game an employee has ordered food delivery through a drone, but lunch breaks are not permitted so Parker needs to intercept and catch the food in a sequence with a side view, throwing items back until the drone crashes.

The game was released on a cartridge, with a box and a full colour manual. The initial run was 1,000 copies.
title: Fork Parker's Crunch Out

description:
Appleseed: Prometheus no Shintaku is a side-scrolling shooter. It's based on Masamune Shirow's cyberpunk sci-fi manga and anime Appleseed, and Shirow worked on it before creating Ghost in the Shell.

Two members of ESWAT, Deunan Knute and Briareos Hecatonchires, must defend the fledgling utopian country of Olympus: one of humanity's last bastions on a world devastated by the catastrophic World War III.

The game is a regular side-scrolling shooter. The characters have a usual side-arm pistol and a special sub-weapon with limited ammunition, which is different for both. They have a range of grenades that they can throw at any time as well. The player has to make his way through various missions, getting briefed each time.
title: Appleseed

description:
Cooly Skunk was a child-friendly 2D platformer being developed by Ukiyotei for the Super Famicom. The 16-bit version was quietly cancelled in favour of a reworked PlayStation version Punky Skunk, but a three-world demo was published for the Satellaview online service.

The story is basically the same: an evil wolf threatens the day with his mouse army, so Cooly Skunk has to set out to defeat him. Cooly Skunk can defeat enemies by swiping his tail, and can also collect various power-ups like a pogo stick and a snowboard to navigate levels.

sample_screenshots.caption: Collected a pogo stick - with these, Cooly Skunk can jump much higher and can defeat anemies by hopping on them.
These enemies descend from the top of the screen. Be careful or they'll catch you!

title: Cooly Skunk: Demo

description:
Bomberman: B-Daman is an action-puzzle game that is based on the B-Daman marble-shooting toys that are based on the Bomberman series.

This game is slightly different from the typical Bomberman titles. It is actually an arcade shooter with puzzle elements. There are 10 levels divided into 10 stages each in the main single-player mode. In order to progress the player has to detonate all the bombs on the screen with a single well-placed shot. This mode can be also played as a turn-based duel for 2 human players.

There is also a 4-player battle mode available. It is a head-to-head single-player or multi-player mode where 4 characters stand on each side of the screen and shoot marbles in the opponents to gain the points.

The player is able to customize the characters' appearance and edit the stages.

An exclusive B-Daman toy known as Yellow Aurora B-Daman (イエローオーロラビーダマン) was included in the game box. It has a marble with JBA (All Japan B-Daman Association) logotype on it.
title: Bomberman: B-Daman

description:
Energy Breaker is set on a small, fictitious island called Zamuria. The story begins with Myra, a 21-year-old girl who has lost her memory. She keeps having dreams warning that she must hurry to avert a catastrophe. After visiting the fortune-teller Selphia who has just come to the Myra's town, she finds herself drawn into a conflict between four mysterious Dark Generals who are seeking the power of four jewels. With the local inventor Renard and his robot assistant Gulliver, they embark on a time-travelling adventure to meet new allies, uncover her forgotten past, and learn of the Dark Generals' plot that may threaten the world.

Energy Breaker is hinted to take place in the same world as Taito's Lufia series: for instance, the presence of Priphea flowers, some terminology and conventions, an obtainable sword named after the Dual Blade, and a cameo appearances by Lufia and Roman in the ending.

Energy Breaker combines gameplay elements from traditional Japanese role-playing games and strategy/tactical role-playing games. The player is able to explore dungeons and towns from the same isometric perspective of the game's battle system. The game features many hidden items that can be found by interacting with the background environment, as well as a staggering amount of descriptive text for the environments that change throughout the course of the game, often several times. The player is able to choose an emotion or attitude when talking to NPCs, however this rarely seems to make a difference. Dungeon exploration transitions seamlessly into episode-like grid-based battle scenarios with preset enemy layouts and conditions as opposed to random encounters. Battles are typically won by defeating all enemies, though other win conditions exists such as defeating a boss, surviving a certain number of turns, or arriving to a specific point of the battle grid.

The battle mechanics are based around a "Balance" component. Player characters and enemies all receive an amount of Balance at the start of their turn, however the less HP a unit has, the less they will receive at the start of that turn. Balance is required to perform most actions, such as moving, performing basic and special attacks, and using items. Special attacks and skills are learned by finding and using "Grimoire" items before battle, and are equipped according to an energy system that consists of four types: blue, red, yellow, and green. One energy type may be leveled up once per level up, up to a maximum of eight. Before they can be used, special skills require the character to meet a specific minimum level of each of the four energy types, which themselves can be continually adjusted throughout the game.
title: Energy Breaker

description:
SD The Great Battle: Aratanaru Chōsen is an action game that crosses over the Ultraman, Kamen Rider and Gundam franchises in Super Deformed style. The story begins when the environmental control system of the SD Nation malfunctions, which revives hordes of evil creatures. Kamen Rider V3, Ultraman Taro and Knight Gundam go on a mission to investigate, but soon disappear. Now the original Kamen Rider, Ultraman and Gundam must find their friends so they can defeat the evil behind it all together.

The game consists of seven levels, seen from a bird's eye perspective, which range from flying islands and mysterious castles to spaceships. The player can switch between the different heroes at any time. Once the missing heroes are found, they can also be used. The levels are full of regular and boss enemies from various incarnations of the three franchises. To defeat them, the heroes can use a standard gun as well as a powerful special weapon unique to each character that requires energy to operate. A helpful ally can be found in each level who will boost the special energy.
title: SD The Great Battle: Aratanaru Chōsen

description:
Cu-On-Pa SFC is a puzzle game in which the player takes control of a cube, the object being to roll this cube over squares of a particular colour. If the top face of the cube matches the colour of the square, it is collected; claim enough squares to move onto the next level.

Essentially, this is a Super Famicom port of the 1995 PC game Endorfun - in fact, Cu-On-Pa is licensed from Endorfun. Cu-On-Pa features none of the new-age stylings of the earlier game, instead opting for a more traditional puzzle game aesthetic. This version offers a couple of new features over Endorfun: there is an Easy Mode, which reduces the available colours from six down to three; and there is also a Puzzle Mode which gives the player predefined boards to solve, and a limited number of moves to do so.

sample_screenshots.caption: A new square is heralded by an impressive lightning bolt.

title: Cu-On-Pa SFC

description:
Sgt. Saunders' Combat! is a turn-based strategy game based on the 1960s television series originally broadcast on the ABC Television Network. Players take command of Sgt. Saunders or one of the other Axis forces during World War II fighting in Europe.

The player uses turns to command units around a map, including movement, attacks, treating wounded characters, exchanging items/weapons, fixing jammed equipment or calling in an artillery strike.
title: Sgt. Saunders' Combat!

description:
The Mahjong Tōhaiden is a one-on-one mahjong simulation game following the Japanese san hako mahjong rule system for two players. It features a variety of different game modes.* Fighting King: a campaign mode in which players choose a character, then take on every other character in the game in one-on-one matches.

  • Free Match: a single-match mode in which players choose both their character and a CPU-controlled character.

  • Actual Mahjong: a one-on-one mode with a persistent customizable player character.

  • Mahjong Tournament: an 11-player tournament mode in which both the player and CPU players compete to become the winner through multiple rounds.

sample_screenshots.caption: Main menu - there are four different game modes.
Each character has a multi-page biography.

title: The Mahjong Tōhaiden

description: In Kawa no Nushi Tsuri 2, you can choose to play as one of four family members, each with unique dialogue and stories. Freely explore 6 unique fishing areas and fill out your logbook - there are many different fish to catch! Feel free to walk, swim and hop over rocks to find tons of different fishing spots! But be careful, wildlife is everywhere waiting to strike!

sample_screenshots.caption: Hmm, I'm pretty scratched up. Maybe I should sleep?

title: Kawa no Nushi Tsuri 2

description:
Socks the Cat is a new frontier in licensed games: presidential pets. Players take on the role of then-President of the United States Bill Clinton's pet cat Socks on a journey of great political importance. Robbers break into the White House and succeed in stealing a portable nuclear missile... and Socks. Players, as Socks, need to break themselves out while also recovering the nuclear missile to save the world.

Players control Socks from a side-scrolling perspective in a typical 2D platformer. Just like most other games in the genre, players can run and jump their way to victory. Being a cat, Socks can also use his claws - this is his main means of protection, with most enemies able to be taken down by a few strategic claw swipes. Players can also pick up a few other items to help them out, such as blocks of cheese that can be thrown to distract mouse enemies. A few levels feature real-world political themes, like the final level set in the White House's famous rose garden, but most feature generic platforming themes like warehouses or sewers. The political theme also shows up in a few bosses which are caricatures of real-world political figures.

sample_screenshots.caption: Socks is front-page news, it seems...
Thieves are making their way out of the White House!
Things look bad for the world in a game over...

title: Socks the Cat: Rocks the Hill

description:
Like its PlayStation cousin, Nichibutsu Arcade Classics is a compilation of ports of several classic Nichibutsu arcade games. This compilation is a bit smaller and simpler than the PlayStation release and contains three games:* Crazy Climber

  • Frisky Tom
  • Moon Cresta

sample_screenshots.caption: Each game has an Arrange mode with better graphics.
Moon Cresta has subtle changes like the sprites and you sometimes see the Moon.
Frisky Tom Arranged Version Title Screen.

title: Nichibutsu Arcade Classics

description: Nichibutsu Arcade Classics 2: Heiankyo Alien is the follow-up to the Super Famicom Nichibutsu Arcade Classics and features two games: a port of the original 1979 arcade game Heiankyo Alien, and a "new type mode" game that reimagines it with updated 16-bit graphics and sound.
title: Nichibutsu Arcade Classics 2: Heiankyo Alien

description:
To prevent the apocalypses from happening, three female warriors endowed with elemental spirits, Rufu, Kairu, and Hamusu, head out to thwart evil and restore the balance between light and darkness.

Battle Zeque-Den is a side scrolling beat-'em-up with light platforming elements made up of six levels. Players get to choose one of the three female characters to play as. The characters are slightly different from each other in their base statistics of speed and attack power. While each character can attack jump, double jump, block, crouch, and also grab enemies, they also have three unique moves each. Two special moves plus they also have a super move that when performed costs them some of their elemental powers. As the game progresses, the females can gain more health and attack power.
title: Battle Zeque Den

description:
Puzzle'N Desu! is a puzzle game where players control a character in a pointed hat.

The aim of the game is to push different colored blocks to form groups of 3 or more and make them disappear. However, unlike Sokoban, pushing a block will make it go all the way until it bumps into another block or the borders of the level, thus, at times, players will need to plan their actions to make sure that all the blocks of one color are gone. The level is considered as complete once players have made all the boxes disappear.

In case players have made a mistake, they can restart the level by pressing L+R on their controllers. However, restarting the level does not restart the timer. Once players run out of time, they lose a life.

The game also includes a multiplayer option, where up to 4 players compete against each other according to the rules that players can set up beforehand. A stage builder is also available in the game. It allows players to create and play through their own stages.

sample_screenshots.caption: 10 Stages await you in this game.
Watch for the timer though, as restarting the level does NOT restart the timer.
Each stage is divided into separate levels.

title: Puzzle'N Desu!

description:
The cute bounty hunter known as Popful Mail looks like she would have no trouble making a living slashing bad guys with her sword. In reality Mail is having a hard time making ends meet. One day, however, she learns about a magician who has gone rogue and has a hefty bounty on his head. Her adventure begins as Popful fights her way through a new adventure, and makes new friends along the way.

Popful Mail is a platform action game with very light RPG elements. As the heroine makes her way through the stages she collects money from slain foes. This money can be used in shops to buy weapons, armor, health, and so on. The game features interaction with many characters through both on-screen dialog and fully animated sequences. Some of these characters become playable as the player progresses through the game.

This release has the same story and general gameplay style as the earlier version, but otherwise was made from scratch, having entirely different graphics, locations, enemies, challenges, etc.

sample_screenshots.caption: Press up on the D-pad to talk to people.

title: Popful Mail

description: Battle Master: Kyūkyoku no Senshi-tachi is a versus fighting game in the style of Street Fighter II, but with a very fast speed. Eight characters from around the world must fight in a tournament, and then defeat a boss from outer space. They use an array of regular punches and kicks, and special moves like fireballs.
title: Battle Master: Kyūkyoku no Senshi-tachi

description:
In Mickey no Tokyo Disneyland Daibōken Mickey arrives in Tokyo Disneyland to a regular job day, where he should meet his friends for practice of dance routines to entertain the park audience, but Minnie told him that Pete tricked their friends to believe that this was a day off. Now Mickey needs to explore the park searching for his friends and stop Pete.

It is a 2D side-scrolling platformer. Mickey can shoot balloons either filled with helium or water to float or hit them respectively.

sample_screenshots.caption: Activate four evil altars to pass the Haunted Mansion

title: Mickey no Tokyo Disneyland Daibōken

description: Kaite Tsukutte Asoberu: Dezaemon is a construction kit for designing and playing arcade-style 2D vertical-scrolling shoot-'em-ups where you can create your own stages. It also includes Daioh Gale, a six-stage spiritual sequel to the arcade game Daioh.
title: Kaite Tsukutte Asoberu: Dezaemon

description: Based on the similarly-named Gundam movie released earlier that year, Kidō Senshi Gundam F91: Senki 0122 puts the player in the role of the Earth Federation, commanding mobile suit armies against the remnants of Zeon. Like many contemporary strategy games, the player moves their units from an overhead view, while battles between units are portrayed through more dynamic cinematic sequences reminiscent of the fights in the shows.
title: Kidō Senshi Gundam F91: Senki 0122

description: Popeye: Ijiwaru Majo Seahag no Maki is a fusion of a board game and an action game. The Seahag, angry for being defeated all the time, uses a magic spell to turn Popeye's friends into stone by stealing their hearts. Now Popeye has to find the pieces, that have been scattered across the five corresponding islands, to bring them back to life.

sample_screenshots.caption: Popeye can use a pipe just as well as Mario

title: Popeye: Ijiwaru Majo Seahag no Maki

description:
F-1 Grand Prix Part II is the second title in Video System's licensed F-1 Grand Prix series.

Based on the 1992 Formula One season, the main feature was the introduction of a Story mode in which the player can create its own team and improve the car over the races.
title: F-1 Grand Prix Part II

description:
F-1 Grand Prix Part III is the third title in Video System's licensed F-1 Grand Prix series.

Based on the 1993 Formula One season, the main gameplay is the same as its predecessor. The ability to switch drivers and engines between teams or the ten-second stop-go penalty are some of the many additions. A few drivers and circuits that weren't part of the 1993 season are also included making it possible to compete in the 1991 and 1992 seasons.

sample_screenshots.caption: Autódromo do Estoril - Joint Test Run ... Euro Disney?

title: F-1 Grand Prix Part III

description:
Super Formation Soccer II is basically the same game as its predecessor Super Formation Soccer.

Significant features include a 4-player mode, battery backup, and a few new gameplay additions.
title: Super Formation Soccer II

sample_screenshots.caption: Climb the wall is this level called.
These melons can be thrown at enemies.

description: Asameshimae Nyanko is a fluffy take on the classic game of reversi. Gameplay takes place on a field divided into squares that represents the classic reversi board, with different-colour cats as reversi pieces. Its major twist is the cute character designs and animations, including fight scenes whenever a player captures another player's pieces. It can be played solo versus the CPU or versus another player.
title: Asameshimae Nyanko

description: Treasure Conflix is a Mode 7 aerial combat adventure with RPG elements. This game is essentially a dogfighting simulation game. To locate important artifacts, the player can speak with several NPCs to learn their whereabouts.
title: Treasure Conflix

description:
Daikaijū Monogatari II is the sequel to Daikaijū Monogatari.

The player is once again embodying the Fire Shell Hero, a legendary champion of the friendly shell monsters, who is summoned to help the shell monsters defeat the evil sorcerer Dark. Dark has managed to locate six of the eggs of the Demon King, who was defeated in the previous game, and used his magics to hatch all six into formidable monster generals. He plans to use these monster generals and their armies to conquer the globe.

sample_screenshots.caption: Can you believe this thing is a CRAB!?
Battle Screen - kinda reminds me of Lufia

title: Daikaijū Monogatari II

description: A group of thieves work against each to get their hands on as much loot as possible, while avoiding law enforcement. The player has a choice of six different thieves, each with their own set of specialties and disadvantages. The game is set on a grid-based board of the town. On each turn, the player must pick an action, roll the dice and control the direction of the thief. Depending on the type of square landed, determines the thief's chances of success or failure.
title: Motteke Oh! Dorobō

description: In Ball Bullet Gun: Survival Game Simulation, the player commands up to six characters in turn based tactical representations of mock Airsoft battles. Among the tactical concerns players are expected to manage are a character's field of view and how many action points a given character can spend per turn.
title: Ball Bullet Gun: Survival Game Simulation

description:
This special edition includes:

  • Street Fighter II Turbo
  • numbered tin box
  • pin featuring the game's logo
title: Street Fighter II Turbo (Limited Edition)

description: Super Bonk 2 is a platformer and the sequel to Super Bonk only ever released in Japan on the Super Famicom. Even more transformations have been included, including girl Bonk. Power-ups from both Super Bonk and Bonk's Revenge for Game Boy are included, but Bonk must use his abilities in even weirder ways like spinning around a pole with his teeth to launch a helicopter. Unlike previous games, after dying, the level must be restarted from the beginning, increasing the difficulty. A password system was also implemented.

sample_screenshots.caption: Enemy fortress flying away in the first stage

title: Chō Genjin 2

description: Taking mechanics straight from the first arcade game, the player enters rally races in one out of five types of racing cars. The game can be practiced in Novice Mode, a fastest time set in the Time Attack mode or an official ranking can be attempted in the World Rally Championship. Some races take place at night with the racing car headlights on.
title: Super Drift Out: World Rally Championships

description:
Jikkyō Powerful Pro Yakyū '94 is a baseball simulation game and the very first title in Konami's long-running Powerful Pro Yakyū franchise. It features a full NPB license and thus all teams and players from the Japanese Pacific and Central leagues as of the end of the 1993 season, as well as 11 real-life stadiums to play in.

The game features four modes: Exhibition mode for one or two players; Mini Pennant mode which is an abbreviated 15-game season; Scenario mode which presents a series of key moments from the previous real-life season; and Camp mode where different aspects of play such as batting, pitching, fielding, and base running can be practiced.
title: Jikkyō Powerful Pro Yakyū '94

description: Dynami Tracer is a sci-fi dialogue-heavy adventure game. It’s a treasure hunt set in space. Players play as one of six characters competing against each other in a race called Dynami Trace. They have two goals: collect as many treasures as possible from different planets and get to the finish line first.
title: Dynami Tracer

description:
Jumpin' Derby is a horse racing simulation game for the Super Famicom. Unlike many games of its genre, it focuses more on the racing itself rather the gambling and management aspects of the sport which are more prominent in series like Derby Stallion or Thoroughbred Breeder.

Players still raise their racehorses, but also take an active role in the races themselves which take place in various locations both common and uncommon to horse racing, such as a beach or the Great Wall of China. There are also parts of the races where the player must leap over obstacles, meaning the player must focus on developing the horse's jumping and running strength.
title: Jumpin' Derby

description:
Due to mysterious malfunctions in the climate control system of their space colony, the heroes of the SD Nation lose their special powers, leading to the nation being overrun by monsters. But there is hope: legend has it that finding and bringing together four special Gachapon capsules will grant the finder a wish. Four heroes set out to find the capsules and restore the peace.

The Great Battle II: Last Fighter Twin is the sequel to SD The Great Battle. Like its predecessor, the game crosses over Bandai's Gundam, Ultraman and Kamen Rider franchises in super deformed style, but switches genres to a side-scrolling Final Fight-style beat'em up, for either one or two players in co-op mode.

The players can choose from four characters: Ultraman Great, Gundam F91, Rider RX, and the Banpresto original Fighter Roar. Characters can be switched at any time during gameplay. To defeat the various enemies (taken from all three franchises), the heroes can use punches, kicks and various combos. A powerful shot can be charged up that will lower the hero's health when used. Collecting and then using the energy capsules dropped by fallen enemies launches a powerful attack that attacks all enemies on screen. In co-op mode, a special two-player combination technique can be used, that, depending on the hero combination, is either an extra powerful attack or heals damage.

The game consists of eight levels, including the space colony, a spaceship, a lunar base, an Egyptian pyramid and more. Each level ends with a boss fight. Some fights lead to alternate routes depending on the players' performance. A password is given after every two levels that allows continuing the game.
title: The Great Battle II: Last Fighter Twin

description:
Maka Maka is an RPG taking place on an Earth where an evil demon king has been defeated over a millennia ago. Now, completely resurrected and full of power again, the demon king wants revenge and organizes his Maka Maka Society to conquer Earth.

Players take control of Corum, a young student who is the reincarnation of the alien prince who initially defeated the demon king who will be joined in his quest to defeat the demon king by a very diverse cast of characters. The game's story and characters all have an absurdist and humorous style to them while battles are random and turn based and well animated for the time, showing how the characters attack one another. All of the main characters are actually reincarnations of great heroes of the past, and, thus, the magic system consists of them transforming into their past selves to use special abilities.

sample_screenshots.caption: Where is my mom and who the hell are you???

title: Maka Maka

description:
Day of the Idea is a surreal turn-based JRPG starring a boy who has psychic powers. The boy is being researched and experimented on by scientists with interest in these powers. He escapes from the laboratory after awakening his psychokinetic powers and killing most of the people in the lab. He then sets out to find out more about his powers and gets involved in a deeper plot. His quest takes him across a dystopian world, picking up an eclectic group of allies along the way.

The equipment system in Idea no Hi is different from most RPGs with players equipping articles of clothing as the armor in the game, giving players many different types of clothing to equip such as headgear, necklaces, undershirts, shirts, pants, underwear, gloves, and shoes. Certain types of clothing can also boost elemental resistances. When equipped with a certain theme of clothing, the character sprites may change to reflect that. Characters can also be cross-dressed and, at one point in the game, the player actually needs to cross-dress the main character to sneak into a town inhabited by women only.

Battles are turn based in a first person perspective similar to Dragon Quest. In the bottom of the screen are a hand drawn portraits of the players party which change their facial expressions with each action taken. The enemy sprites in-battle are also large and detailed, having unique animations for each of their attacks. The enemy encounters are random when travelling on the world map while in dungeons, they are visible and dash towards the player once he is in their sight.

Up to four characters participate in battles with a fifth slot reserved for pets. The pet can participate in battles, however, it can't be controlled by the player. Different pets can be recruited throughout the game, but, unlike the party, they can't level up, giving players a good reason to switch to a new pet once it is recruited.
title: Day of the Idea

description:
Benkei Gaiden: Suna no Shō is the sequel to the PC Engine RPG Benkei Gaiden. The game is a turn-based role-playing game with random encounters utilizing a first-person battle system similar to Dragon Quest. The influence extends to the interaction menu, which features multiple verb commands.

The year is 1274; eighty-two years have passed since the capital was established in Kamakura. The Mongolian army, establishing its rule over China, has attacked Japan and conquered the city of Hakata. However, the Mongolian army has also suffered a devastating blow from a sudden storm and was forced to retreat. Emperor Kublai Khan, sensing that the storm was caused by a powerful spell, gathered sorcerers from his country and China and appointed one of the sorcerers as a general, sending him to conquer Japan.

Thus, the events of the game take place in 13th-century Japan, China, Mongolia, and Korea. The Mongols that infiltrate Japan use magic to create a large number of monsters, causing chaos and throwing Japan into a state of panic. The game starts with the protagonist setting out to exterminate the monsters infesting Japan with the help of a temple's chief priest.

The entire story is divided into two parts: the Japanese part and the Chinese mainland part.

The Japanese part deals with the protagonist searching for six crystals needed to break the barrier and wake up Benkei to defeat the cursed army.

The Mainland China part makes players travel across a vast map to the mainland in order to defeat the remaining three generals and Kublai Khan. It goes in some odd directions, such as having players travel through water with dinosaurs, adding time travel to the plot, being in a world where gods live in multiple dimensions, and other plot twists that are mixed with historical facts of that time period.
title: Benkei Gaiden: Suna no Shō

description:
Tying in with the promotion for All Japan’s Pro Wrestling, Fire Pro Joshi All-Star Dream Slam has 26 different Joshi star wrestlers of the early 90s. There are five different game modes to play:

  • Exhibition Match - A straightforward versus match. Can be played in a Regular style match or the Winning Road matches to become the top Joshi champion.
  • Open League - The wrestler or wrestling team goes up against seven opponents in an all-play-all tournament style.
  • Tournament - Like the Open League mode, but plays in seven bracket-structured Regular matches.
  • Elimination - Can be played with wrestlers as singles or tag teams with the aim of beating four other opponents one after the other until there is a last one standing.
  • Battle Royals - A match with four wrestlers battling at the same time. The winner is the last one standing.

Moves will change depending on the wrestlers’ postures like in a headlock or being downed on the mat. Certain rules can be set such as allowing or preventing being outside the ring and how many seconds an opponent should be pinned down before a victory can be declared.
title: Fire Pro Joshi All-Star Dream Slam

description:
This title in the Fire Pro wrestling series introduces new features, with a variety of over 80 wrestlers, who are based on real life wrestlers as well as Japanese and American organizations, plus hidden unlockable wrestlers. The player can utilize dozens of moves to tackle, counter, pin, and resist the opponent.

The game can be played in six different modes:

  • World Championship - Allows the player to save between matches and racks up points dependent on how the player wins.
  • One Night Dram Match - A single match in which options can be configured to bend the rules .
  • Exciting Tournament - A tournament with 3 to 16 wrestlers with matches happening in rapid succession and no recuperation throughout. Saving can be done in this mode.
  • Mega Fight League - A bracket structured tournament with as few as four teams and a maximum of 32, the winner being there one with the highest number of points. Allows saving between matches.
  • Elimination Match - Five single team matches played continuously with no recuperation in between. The goal is to eliminate all wrestlers before taking out the team captain.
  • Hyper Battle Royal - Four wrestlers fight in the ring at once, the winner being the last one standing.

The player also has the option to custom edit wrestlers cosmetically and by their traits, then save them.
title: Super Fire Pro Wrestling X

description:
Super Fire Pro Wrestling Special is another entry in the Fire Pro wrestling series. There is a variety of over 100 wrestlers associated with 15 different organizations (each with their own wrestling ring). The player has the option of creating a custom wrestler for matches. New to the series is a story mode, focused on the downfallen wrestler Morio Smith as the protagonist, who is hoping to become top champion and rebuild his career.

The game has four different modes:

  • One Night Match - Two-in-One mode, including One Match mode, which can be played as a single or tag team, or the Battle Royals mode for a match with four wrestlers simultaneously. Also incorporates a n unlockable Gruesome Fighting mode.
  • Tournament - From 8 to 16 wrestlers battle and win elimination style, the winner being the last one standing.
  • Open League - The player will face every single wrestler, playing match after match to go for the highest possible ranking.
  • Champion Road - The main story of the game, in which the player can play the role of Morio Smith or a custom wrestler.
title: Super Fire Pro Wrestling Special

description:
The first of the Fire Pro Wrestling series on the Super Famicom pits two or four out of 24 different wrestlers against each other in a wrestling ring shown from an isometric perspective, with the referee keeping tabs. The game can be played in five different modes:

  • World Championship - Playing as a single or tag team, the player’s goal is to accumulate victory points to qualify for matches against tougher opponents, otherwise the game ends early. To exclude points, the player can opt for the Title Defense Mode.
  • Exhibition - This can be played with as a single or tag team. Certain rules like the time limit and number of rounds can be set to the player’s preference.
  • Elimination - Played in tag teams, which requires the player to beat all members, including the reserves of the opposing team. The team members can be preset or customized.
  • Open League - Uses the point system of the World Championship, but there are fewer opponents to fight.
  • Wrestling Tutorial - Teaches the player within five matches to get a grasp of the controls and techniques.
title: Super Fire Pro Wrestling

description:
Battle Cross draws inspiration from classic games as Super Sprint or Badlands, employing a top-down perspective, but spicing things up with collectible items such as bombs or weapons to hinder opponents.

The objective of the game is to control a fleet of small futuristic air bikes and navigate through various race tracks. Players compete against each other to determine who can reach the finish line first. Each track presents different hazards, including puddles, speed bumps, pinball bumpers, and even cannonballs. There are a total of 12 courses, including a hidden bonus course.

The Multitap is supported and up to 5 human players can play together at the same time.
title: Battle Cross

description:
The Fire Pro Wrestling series continues in Super Fire Pro Wrestling 2, the second Super Famicom installment with 28 different wrestlers, new fighting moves and new additions within four different game modes:

  • World Championship - The player can pick a single wrestler or tag team with the goal of winning matches, earning as many points as possible to climb up the ranks for top place. The are two additional unlockable sub modes, being the Title Defense mode that ignores the points system, and the Handicap Tornado Tag Challenge with the player’s wrestling doing each match against a tag team.
  • Exhibition - Matches can be played as a single, tag team or handicap tech for extra challenge. Adjusting the rules such as the time limit or out of bounds allowed affects the difficulty.
  • Elimination - Two preset or custom teams of five wrestlers face off until all opponents are eliminated from the ring.
  • Open League - Playing as a single or tag team, the player has to beat all 8 or 16 opponents with a qualifying total number of points.
title: Super Fire Pro Wrestling 2

description:
Super Fire Pro Wrestling III: Final Bout is the third Super Famicom installment of the Fire Pro Wrestling series. It is a major step up with up to 64 wrestlers, plus 12 custom wrestler slots (not found in the Easy Type re-release), all playable in six different game modes:

  • One Night Dream Match - This mode can be played as a single, tag team or handicap match with configurable options for the rules.
  • World Championship - playing as a single or tag team, the player challenges all wrestlers in the roster through the highest victory point score. Getting far in this mode unlocks the Title Match mode, which features the toughest opponents. Exclusive to the Easy Type re-release, the tough opponents are selectable by default.
  • Open League - Different from the previous installment is 5e lack of tag teams, with the player required to beat 8 opponents with the highest number of points.
  • Elimination - With a compliment of five wrestlers, the player challenges an opposing team of five until each wrestler is eliminated from the game.
  • Tournament - The player as a single or tag team competes against eight opponents, bracket by bracket.
  • Battle Royale - A new introduction to the series pits four wrestlers together in the ring until only one wrestler is left standing.
title: Super Fire Pro Wrestling III: Final Bout

description:
Decades after the defeat of Ragon, an amnesiac man journeys across Minelvaton to battle the forces of the Darkness God Zuni, search for the missing Prince Kyral, and confront Ragon’s brother Zolde, while trying to discover his origin.

Many of the game mechanics are derived from the first Silva Saga game, but with some significant differences. The menu options and inventory system are reduced for easier and quicker navigation. In addition to members joining the player’s companion party as the story progresses, it is also possible to hire up to four combat-specialized mercenaries. The player can also acquire four other units called idols, which are frail, but good at spellcasting. Random battles are now completely turn-based and option-driven, in which the player will battle with the companion party by default, but can switch them for the mercenary or idol party, both of which act completely independent of player control.
title: Silva Saga II: The Legend of Light and Darkness

description:
Dottie Flowers is a fangame created by a single developer and based on the game Turrican. Like Turrican, the gameplay of Dottie Flowers primarly consists of progressing through stages while platforming and firing large amounts of laser-like bullets. In Dottie Flowers, the player's main weapon is a high-tech magic broomstick and a combo counter is present in the right-hand corner of the screen, tracking how many hits the player has inflicted on enemies without taking damage themselves.

Dottie Flowers was initially exclusive to physical Super Nintendo Entertainment System cartridges sent to 100 people who mailed in postcards to a physical address provided at the end of a digitally-released Dottie Flowers demo. However, in March 2024, an emulator download for the game was made available on the game's official webpage.

The game takes place in Cologne, Germany, where Dottie Flower's developer grew up and where some of the games created by the Turrican developers, Rainbow Arts Software GmbH, were made.
title: Dottie Flowers

description: Sotsugyō Bangai-hen: Nee Mahjong Shiyo! ("Graduation Side Story: Hey, Let's Play Mahjong!") is a spinoff of Graduation that combines the story and concept of helping a group of students graduate high school with mahjong gameplay. The main story mode follows one year of helping the students, with the teacher helping one group of three students each month; this takes the form of a game of mahjong, and each girl's stats are affected by their ranking in that month's game, which in turn affects which ending they get. There is also a free battle mode where the player can pick any three characters to play against.
title: Sotsugyō Bangai-hen: Nee Mahjong Shiyo!

description: Super Fishing Bigfight is a cartoon-style bass fishing game. The game is divided into five stages, each of which is a timed tournament with a specific target fish. The player must catch smaller fish to build their ranking before attempting to catch the target fish on each stage. The only customization options are a selection of lures which can be changed at any time.
title: Super Fishing Bigfight

description: Super Mad Champ is a motorbike racing game, which allows players to attack opponents during the course of the race, and includes obstacles. The player has a choice of five different riders. There are two different modes; Career Mode, and Time Attack (for practice). In the Career Mode, the player starts with $40,000. To race, the player has pay a subscription fee for one of the three Grand Prix entry classes. Winning a race with a decent rank yields prize money, which can purchase a new and better motorbike, or parts.
title: Super Mad Champ

description:
In times past, a hero's use of three sacred relics have kept the Scarlet Lotus Castle town safe from a monster invasion. The relics were stored away in three separate dungeons. As time passes, monsters start reappearing again causing unrest among the townsfolk. The king decides to send a party of adventurers into the dungeons to retrieve the relics so they can put a stop to the current monster invasion.

Wizardry: Throb of the Demon's Heart is a first person dungeon crawler. Players create characters for there six person party at the training hall. Character creation offers 11 different races and 14 different classes to choose from, there alignment (good, evil, or neutral) and whether they're male or female. Characters have stats for strength, intelligence, piety, vitality, agility, and luck. Players can also import their characters from Wizardry: The Third Episode - Scripture of the Dark.

The game sticks close to the earliest Wizardry games. The town is explored through a menu, with the town having a tavern, shop. temple, and inn. The game has 3 dungeons to explore plus the training grounds which is a location in which players can gain experience on enemies they have already defeated in the other dungeons.

It is also worth noting that the game has a normal mode and a mania mode. In mania mode, the game will constantly auto-save thus possibly putting the player in a tough predicament if they go into a dungeon unprepared.
title: Wizardry: Throb of the Demon's Heart

description: Earth Light takes place in a far future where humanity has begun colonizing space. The player commands Earth Federation forces in their fight against the Galt Empire, a collection of space colonies that declared independence from the former. They move squads of mechs along a hex-based grid and fight Galt forces where possible. Fights unfold much like in Advance Wars or Warsong, where both squadrons pit all their available fighters against each other simultaneously hoping to eliminate the other.
title: Earth Light

description: Pro Mahjong Tsuwamono is a mahjong game featuring the likenesses of 16 professional players, and the first title in Culture Brain's Tsuwamono mahjong series. The game includes a free battle mode against any selection of pro players, a tournament mode with three different titles to earn, a parlor mode with four different specific situations, and a mahjong guidance mode that advises players on how to improve their mahjong gameplay.
title: Pro Mahjong Tsuwamono

description:
Sound Novel Tkool is a game creation toolkit that allows the user to create their own sound novel adventure games. It is part of ASCII's Tkool series of such software packages. It allows the player to write the text of their story, choose background and character silhouette graphics, then add music, sound effects, and visual effects from a large variety of premade assets.

Included is a sample game in two parts, which tells the story of a young man who met a mysterious girl when he was eight years old, then ten years later receives a message from her and goes to meet her again. The sample game can be used as a template or reference for the player's own game, or simply enjoyed as its own short story. Additional assets were also available for download via Nintendo's Satellaview service.
title: Sound Novel Tkool

description: America! Ōdan Ultra Quiz features the license of the aforementioned Japanese game show. The game show is focused on asking its contestants questions that deal with several topics about the United States of America. The game is a mix of these questions and an assortment of mini-games. The game offers both a Normal or Easy difficulty level.
title: America! Ōdan Ultra Quiz

description:
Wally wo Sagase! Ehon no Kuni no features the character Waldo (known generally as Wally internationally) from the Where's Waldo franchise. The plot involves Waldo and his Waldo Watchers getting together to celebrate Wenda's birthday along with Where's Waldo author Martin Handford. However, Waldo's nemesis Odlaw sneaks in and swipes Waldo's magic walking stick and then uses it to scatter 99 Waldo Watchers all over the land. Now its up to Waldo and a lone Waldo Watcher to find the other Waldo Watchers and also find a present for Wenda.

The game is set up where the player will be shown a picture of something (a person or object) and then will take control of a Waldo Watcher and guides him through areas that will contain the object somewhere. The player will be given a limited number of chances to select the correct object that matches what is shown in the picture. The player will be able to walk around the lands of civilizations such as ones with prehistoric cavemen, ancient Egyptians, Vikings. and Medieval times.

The game has some light puzzle solving as some of the Waldo Watchers are locked away and the player will need to figure out a way to rescue them by doing things like stepping on buttons to lower walls or by using teleporters in the correct order.
title: Wally wo Sagase! Ehon no Kuni no Daibōken

description:
Parker Brothers real estate trading board game comes to the Super Famicom and is a different production that shouldn't be confused with the other Super Nintendo version of Monopoly,

The game has both a single player mode and a multiplayer mode, In the single player mode, players get to explore the Monopoly Mansion. The mansion hosts several rooms. Some rooms include a trophy room, a tutorial room, and a Monopoly quiz room. Most importantly behind seven of the doors are rooms full of four Monopoly opponents each. Each rooms opponents are somewhat randomized from a pool of 35 different opponents. the randomization takes their AI skill level into account. The goal of the game is to beat the players in each room at a game of Monopoly. Once that is accomplished, the player can take on the ultimate challenge of trying to beat the opponents in the Masters room. If the player manages to beat the Master's room, a free play room will become available.
title: Monopoly

description:
Super UNO is a videogame adaption of the shedding card playing game UNO,

The game features a tutorial mode, and a Mission mode. The mission mode is a mix of both board game and card game.

The Mission mode consists of four boards that culminate with a boss card battle at the end. During the board game portion, players can earn items and will be forced to participate in mini-game events. If the player defeats all of the boards, they will be given an opportunity to play a fifth board and will get a chance to have a battle with the UNO King.
title: Super Uno

alternate_titles.title: Super Formation Soccer 94: World Cup Final Data

description:
Based on the 1994 FIFA World Cup tournament, Super Formation Soccer 94 features 24 different national soccer teams, 9 unlockable hidden teams, and a few sponsors such as Snickers and Adidas. There are four different play modes:

  • Exhibition - Allows up to four players to pick a National or All Star Team and play against each other or the CPU.
  • World Cup - Play as any of the teams that qualified in the 1994 World Cup, beat the opposing teams and win the grand trophy.
  • League - The player builds a roster of 8 teams and picks one to beat the rest.
  • Tournament - The player picks a team and plays a series of matches against one team after another.

A few months later, another release called Super Formation Soccer 94: World Cup Final Data came out with some a new replay mode and updates to the teams' stats.
title: Super Formation Soccer 94: World Cup Edition
